title: Ruben Dias , the leader :  There no such thing as a lost ball for him

â€œHe was a young kid just starting in the game but you could see a few signs that he might become a leader one day. He was always talking on the pitch: telling people where to move, trying to assist his team-mates. He was a helper on the pitch.â€
City were in the market for a Vincent Kompany replacement when they signed Dias in 2020 â€” their influential captain had left the club a year earlier and they had missed his leadership the season afterwards as Liverpool won the Premier League title.

That, though, was the last time that City were not named champions. Other factors also contributed to the team clicking into gear a few months after Dias arrived but he is certainly one of the reasons they have won 10 trophies since 2020.

He was voted into Cityâ€™s captaincy group after his first season in Manchester and one video from the Netflix documentary charting the clubâ€™s treble-winning campaign shows him in action, rallying the troops during the run-in.

â€œAnd the best thing we have is that now weâ€™ve done it (won the Premier League in 2022-23), and they think, â€˜Oh, theyâ€™re tiredâ€™, but we want to do it again â€” and thatâ€™s when we get big,â€ he says in the clip.

The final footage was a cut-down version of a much longer speech. â€œHeâ€™s a bit intense in how he works, sometimes a bit too much for me,â€ Bernardo continues, â€œbut that shows his passion for the game.â€

â€œThatâ€™s very rare. Most Portuguese players are too focused on their personal objectives in the match but what Ruben did, because of his communication, was bring players together as a team for the teamâ€™s objectives as opposed to just each one pulling in their own direction.â€
Dias was so vocal, in fact, that he was told to tone it down once he started to break into the Benfica first team at 18, and one of the biggest things he had to work on was channelling his feedback.
â€œOne time, in pre-season training, when Ruben was called up to the senior team the first few times for Benfica under Rui Vitoria, at the end of the training, we went to him and said, â€˜Look, youâ€™ve got to calm it down because some of the players have been here for like 10, 20 years, and so you canâ€™t just be shooting off with all these orders and being so vocal all the timeâ€™. But that was Ruben.â€
Vitoria, speaking to The Athletic, explains how he wanted to mould Diasâ€™ communication skills.
â€œPlaying at a higher level, in Benficaâ€™s main team and with the profile of colleagues that he had, it was essential that, at the same time, he had an idea of who he was communicating with,â€ he says.
â€œThere was permanent and constant communication with all the players on the team. We often heard him, from centre-back, talking to the left-winger. That could also be harmful for him. It was essential that he focused on communicating with the players around him, namely in the defensive sector and in midfield, or, if he communicated with someone further away, that this did not distract him from his task.

â€œConstantly communicating and alerting colleagues can sometimes create problems for you. This work was slow and gradual, but Ruben understood, and he, being an attentive boy, kept improving and was able to do it.â€
Interestingly, when asked what else stood out about Dias during their time together, Vitoria highlighted his work away from football.
â€œWhat I thought at that time was that he had something which is necessary for all players today, which is an attractive commercial side,â€ says Vitoria, who is now in charge of Panathinaikos.
â€œIn fact, from a certain point onwards, he also began to worry about his image, and that was something that from the beginning, we also thought would have to happen. Not that he didnâ€™t have an image, but today, in addition to being a player, he is also a very attractive image off the field.
â€œHe created this more universal dimension. Now people also know him in another way. We know Ruben as a player but we also have access to moments of him when he is in his private life and on vacation, for example, in which he clearly demonstrates another part of the player and the human being â€” this is an aspect that is also worth highlighting.â€
Speaking to The Athletic for a closer look at Dias and other playersâ€™ off-pitch branding, Paulo Malva do Vale, an expert in commercial strategy, explained recently how the Portugal defender wants to essentially create a brand around the key strengths of his game.
â€œRuben felt like there was much more to his character than what he was showing on the pitch, and already that was a lot,â€ Malva do Vale says. â€œWe said, â€˜Letâ€™s identify your brand space, your core values, and then create a brand architecture around you in the same way that a corporation wouldâ€™.â€
The captions that accompany his posts on X and Instagram would probably be more at home on the business-focused LinkedIn, with an almost Silicon Valley-esque motivational tone, which is a little different from most footballersâ€™ approach but is ultimately very faithful to the real Dias.

Bernardo was speaking in Lisbon, Portugal, at a time when Dias was out injured with a calf injury, the result of playing too many matches without a break, something which put him back on the sidelines in December.
Dias says he returned into a â€œdeath sequenceâ€ at the time, with Cityâ€™s other defenders also injured, meaning he had to play through pain again until he could no longer continue. He returned in January, but picked up another problem against Paris Saint-Germain.
But his return is a timely boost for the latest clash with Madrid, having made that comeback against Orient on Saturday. There, he was selected as a guiding presence alongside debutant Vitor Reis, the 19-year-old Brazilian defender, a role he would not doubt relish given he has been doing the guiding and coaching even when it was he who was the newcomer.
There is no doubt that Cityâ€™s season so far has been difficult, not just the worst of Diasâ€™ four years at the club but quite possibly since they won the Premier League for the first time under Roberto Mancini in 2012. But if anybody can see the positives â€” and inspire others to do the same â€” it is Ruben Dias.
